Jason,

In my experience, the only compelling examples are those that are 
=
similar to the problems you are trying to solve. Until you attempt a 
probl=
em that requires you to obtain an answer, and that problem falls 
outside t=
he current implementation constraints, all is well and there 
is no justifi=
cation to press further.

The material supplied is an attempt to clarify th=
e bounds of the 
current implementation, and outline suggestions for when t=
he demands 
of the current problem necessitate pushing the bounds circumscr=
ibed 
by the current problem.

At the point at which necessity reveals that=
 the current 
implementation is not adequate, there will also exist the 
ju=
stification to invest the time. That is where I am at presently, 
and the m=
aterial supplied is intended for those similarly situated.

Thanks,
Andy Ca=
rl

nt you are

larger of

plain and understand, and also 
shows how

nsor arrays with its understanding of

cause to be honest it's hard for me to invest time 
in

rmalism without a compelling example.

> On 5/20/07, afcarl2 <a.carl@...>=
 wrote:
> >
> >   The following is a proposed generalization of the HyperNE=
AT 
concept
> > from its present implementation. The objectives are two-fol=
d. 
First,
> > to expand the scope of problems in which the HyperNEAT appro=
ach 
may
> > be applied. Second, to enable evolved partition of the design =

space,
> > so as to enable application of the HyperNEAT approach to proble=
ms
> > which contain highly discontinuous and divergent natures in 
differe=
nt
> > portions of the design space. It is intended to provide a starting
>=
 > point for further thought and interchange of ideas, with the 
focus on
>=
 > achieving the stated objectives by whatever means or changes which
> > m=
ay emerge.
> >
> > 1 - Preliminary Definitions: Given an arbitrary point "P=
" in 
design
> > space, comprised of the following:
> > (a) problem specifi=
c inputs (PSIs);
> > (b) auxiliary additional parameters associated w/ PSIs=
 (i.e. 
includes
> > geometry);
> > (c) problem specific outputs (PSOs);
> =
> (d) auxiliary additional parameters associated w/ PSOs (i.e. 
includes
> =
> geometry);
> > (e) Substrate Inputs: comprised of PSIs, "a" above;
> > (f=
) Substrate Outputs: comprised of PSOs, "c" above;
> > (g) CPPN Inputs: com=
prised of auxiliary additional parameters
> > associated w/ PSIs & PSOs, "b=
" & "d" above;
> > (h) CPPN Output: weight between current pair of substrat=
e nodes;
> > (i) An "experience_point" is defined as a struct containing 
i=
tems "a"
> > through "d" above;
> > (j) The "Experience" is defined as a ve=
ctor of experience_points;
> >
> > 2 - Current HyperNEAT Implementation:
> =
> (a) CPPN Inputs comprised of (1-b) and (1-d) are each constant in
> > num=
ber and meaning as you loop over the links in the substrate
> > network (i.=
e. 3D CPPN "From" Input: quan. =3D 3, meaning =3D X, Y & Z
> > coordinates)=

> >
> > 3 - Proposed Generalization For CPPN Input:
> > (a) the quantity a=
nd meaning of auxiliary additional parameters
> > associated w/ PSIs (1-b) =
can vary over the substrate network (i.e.
> > dimensionality of substrate i=
nputs, hidden and output nodes);
> > (b) the quantity and meaning of auxili=
ary additional parameters
> > associated w/ PSOs (1-d) can vary over the su=
bstrate network (i.e.
> > dimensionality of substrate inputs, hidden and ou=
tput nodes);
> > (c) CPPN Input "From": the quantity and meanings are defin=
ed to be
> > the superset of possible auxiliary additional parameters 
asso=
ciated
> > w/ PSIs and PSOs (i.e. 5D CPPN "From" Input: quan. =3D 5, meanin=
g =3D 
X,
> > Y, Z, apples & oranges);
> > (d) CPPN Input "To": the quantit=
y and meanings are defined to be 
the
> > superset of possible auxiliary ad=
ditional parameters associated w/
> > PSIs and PSOs (i.e. 5D CPPN "To" Inpu=
t: quan. =3D 5, meaning =3D X, 
Y, Z,
> > apples & oranges);
> > (e) the me=
aning of any given CPPN Input node, for both "From"
> > or "To", remains co=
nstant (i.e. only apples are presented on the
> > apples input node);
> > (=
f) the quantity of zero is presented on any CPPN Input node whose
> > dimen=
sionality, or meaning, is not present/applicable for the 
current
> > CPPN =
Input "From" or "To";
> >
> > 4 - Proposed Generalization For Evolved Parti=
tion of Design Space:
> > (a) Evaluation of speciation of CPPN population a=
long design space
> > partition lines, as defined by allocation of experien=
ce_points
> > addressed by a specific species (i.e. species "0" by default
=
> > addresses all experience_points, species "1" through "n" addresses
> > =
only those experience_points which yield a higher absolute fitness
> > than=
 species "0";
> > (b) species fitness computed based upon percentage of
> >=
 experience_points yielding a highest absolute fitness among all
> > specie=
s (i.e. if species "1" gave best fitness for 25 percent of 
the
> > experie=
nce_points, then the species fitness would be the 
summation of
> > fitness=
 for those specific experience_points);
> > (c) objective to maximize overa=
ll fitness of "Experience" as
> > summation of best individual from each sp=
ecies over those
> > experience_points for which they were evolved and main=
tained the 
best
> > fitness (i.e. all experience_points addressed only onc=
e);
